docs.snippet: The latest hotly-anticipated “app phone” — a term David Pogue Twit-sourced — is the Motorola Droid. It runs on Verizon and Google’s Android operating system (the 2.0 version) and the design, Pogue writes, “screams...
docs.lead_paragraph: The latest hotly-anticipated “app phone” — a term David Pogue Twit-sourced — is the Motorola Droid. It runs on Verizon and Google’s Android operating system (the 2.0 version) and the design, Pogue writes, “screams ‘Star Wars,’ if not ‘Darth Vader.’ It’s jet-black, all sharp angles and industrial-looking edges.” It’s super-fast, with good audio quality, a pull-out screen and a stellar GPS. The Droid may not be an iPhone killer, Pogue writes, but it is “a killer phone.” Get it starting tomorrow for $200 after a $100 rebate (Pogue’s tip: “Get it at Best Buy, where you get the rebate on the spot”) and play with it in your man cave.

headline.main: Is This the Droid You’re Looking For?
headline.print_headline: Is This the Droid You’re Looking For?

docs.snippet: "Advertising becomes more important, not less important" as new technologies like cloud computing and the mobile Web continue to emerge, Eric Schmidt of Google said, because it helps consumers "sort out information" and connects to them "in a huma...
docs.lead_paragraph: The business card of Eric Schmidt says he is the chairman and chief executive of Google. But another part of his job is ambassador to the marketing, advertising and media communities, reassuring them that if Google is a "frenemy," in the parlance of Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of WPP, it is more "friend" than "enemy."

headline.main: Stressing the 'Friend' Part of 'Frenemy'

docs.abstract: "Advertising becomes more important, not less important" as new technologies like cloud computing and the mobile Web continue to emerge, Eric Schmidt of Google said, because it helps consumers "sort out information" and connects to them "in a human way."

docs.snippet: He talks about Google, President Obama and his own retirement....
docs.lead_paragraph: Folks in the media are so used to considering Rupert Murdoch as a spectral presence that it is sometimes hard to remember that behind a name so freighted with meaning lurks a real actual guy. That's why it's fun spending time watching Sky News Australia's 37-minute interview with him. There is no major news splash, but there is value in watching Mr. Murdoch's mind and mouth work in the long on-camera interview with Sky's David Speers last week.

headline.main: Rupert Murdoch: Unalloyed, Unbound

docs.abstract: He talks about Google, President Obama and his own retirement.

docs.snippet: E-readers like Amazon’s Kindle have caught on with the small set willing to buy a device just for reading. But pretty soon, most of us will read books — or at least parts of them — on our ubiquitous smartphones. Forexample, Shortcovers, a To...
docs.lead_paragraph: E-readers like Amazon’s Kindle have caught on with the small set willing to buy a device just for reading. But pretty soon, most of us will read books — or at least parts of them — on our ubiquitous smartphones. Forexample, Shortcovers, a Toronto-based company, has created free reading apps for the iPhone, BlackBerry and Palm Pre, as well as for Google’s Android phones. There are many free books available. Newer best sellers cost $10.Paul boutin.

headline.main: How to Read

So far it's only talk, but Advertising Age decided to do some math to look at the implications of such a move.

docs.snippet: From Petaluma to Peshawar, volunteer cartographers are logging details of neighborhoods near and far....
docs.lead_paragraph: They don't know it, but people who use Google's online maps may be getting directions from Richard Hintz. Mr. Hintz, a 62-year-old engineer who lives in Berkeley, Calif., has tweaked the locations of more than 200 business listings and points of interest in cities across the state, sliding an on-screen place marker down the block here, moving another one across the street there. Farther afield, he has mapped parts of Cambodia and Laos, where he likes to go on motorcycle trips.

headline.main: Online Maps: Everyman Offers New Directions

docs.snippet: Flying during the holidays is never fun. But a couple of airlines are trying to brighten up the process with a gift of free Wi-Fi access at 10,000 feet.     Through Jan. 15, Virgin America, in a promotion with Google, will offer its Gogo Inflight ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Flying during the holidays is never fun. But a couple of airlines are trying to brighten up the process with a gift of free Wi-Fi access at 10,000 feet. Through Jan. 15, Virgin America, in a promotion with Google, will offer its Gogo Inflight Internet free on all flights. The service is normally $5.95 for very short flights to $12.95 for flights over three hours.

headline.main: Free Wi-Fi in the Sky And Some in the Terminal

docs.abstract: Virgin America and Delta Airlines are offering free inflight Internet service during holidays; Google will provide complimentary Wi-Fi in 47 airports across US; photo (S)

docs.snippet: Italian prosecutors on Wednesday asked a judge to give prison sentences to three Google executives and one former executive accused of defamation and failure to comply with privacy laws.      The prosecutors contend that Google was negligent becau...
docs.lead_paragraph: Italian prosecutors on Wednesday asked a judge to give prison sentences to three Google executives and one former executive accused of defamation and failure to comply with privacy laws. The prosecutors contend that Google was negligent because it allowed a video of high school students bullying a disabled classmate to remain on its Italian-language video service for two months in 2006. The company, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., says it removed the video several hours after being alerted of its existence.

headline.main: Italian Prosecutors Call for Prison in a Google Case

docs.abstract: Italian prosecutors request prison sentences for three current and one former Google executives accused of defamation and failure to comply with privacy laws for allowing video of high school students bullying disabled classmate; ask for one year sentences for senior vice president David C Drummond, global privacy counsel Peter Fleischer and former chief financial officer George Reyes; prosecutors are seeking six-month sentence for British consumer marketing head in Britain Arvind Desikan (S
